speaker: FLAVIUS
line: Hence! home, you idle creatures get you home:

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: Is this a holiday? what! know you not,

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: Being mechanical, you ought not walk

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: Upon a labouring day without the sign

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: Of your profession? Speak, what trade art thou?

speaker: First Commoner
line: Why, sir, a carpenter.

speaker: MARULLUS
line: Where is thy leather apron and thy rule?

speaker: MARULLUS
line: What dost thou with thy best apparel on?

speaker: MARULLUS
line: You, sir, what trade are you?

speaker: Second Commoner
line: Truly, sir, in respect of a fine workman, I am but,

speaker: Second Commoner
line: as you would say, a cobbler.

speaker: MARULLUS
line: But what trade art thou? answer me directly.

speaker: Second Commoner
line: A trade, sir, that, I hope, I may use with a safe

speaker: Second Commoner
line: conscience; which is, indeed, sir, a mender of bad soles.

speaker: MARULLUS
line: What trade, thou knave? thou naughty knave, what trade?

speaker: Second Commoner
line: Nay, I beseech you, sir, be not out with me: yet,

speaker: Second Commoner
line: if you be out, sir, I can mend you.

speaker: MARULLUS
line: What meanest thou by that? mend me, thou saucy fellow!

speaker: Second Commoner
line: Why, sir, cobble you.

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: Thou art a cobbler, art thou?

speaker: Second Commoner
line: Truly, sir, all that I live by is with the awl: I

speaker: Second Commoner
line: meddle with no tradesman's matters, nor women's

speaker: Second Commoner
line: matters, but with awl. I am, indeed, sir, a surgeon

speaker: Second Commoner
line: to old shoes; when they are in great danger, I

speaker: Second Commoner
line: recover them. As proper men as ever trod upon

speaker: Second Commoner
line: neat's leather have gone upon my handiwork.

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: But wherefore art not in thy shop today?

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: Why dost thou lead these men about the streets?

speaker: Second Commoner
line: Truly, sir, to wear out their shoes, to get myself

speaker: Second Commoner
line: into more work. But, indeed, sir, we make holiday,

speaker: Second Commoner
line: to see Caesar and to rejoice in his triumph.

speaker: MARULLUS
line: Wherefore rejoice? What conquest brings he home?

speaker: MARULLUS
line: What tributaries follow him to Rome,

speaker: MARULLUS
line: To grace in captive bonds his chariot-wheels?

speaker: MARULLUS
line: You blocks, you stones, you worse than senseless things!

speaker: MARULLUS
line: O you hard hearts, you cruel men of Rome,

speaker: MARULLUS
line: Knew you not Pompey? Many a time and oft

speaker: MARULLUS
line: Have you climb'd up to walls and battlements,

speaker: MARULLUS
line: To towers and windows, yea, to chimney-tops,

speaker: MARULLUS
line: Your infants in your arms, and there have sat

speaker: MARULLUS
line: The livelong day, with patient expectation,

speaker: MARULLUS
line: To see great Pompey pass the streets of Rome:

speaker: MARULLUS
line: And when you saw his chariot but appear,

speaker: MARULLUS
line: Have you not made an universal shout,

speaker: MARULLUS
line: That Tiber trembled underneath her banks,

speaker: MARULLUS
line: To hear the replication of your sounds

speaker: MARULLUS
line: Made in her concave shores?

speaker: MARULLUS
line: And do you now put on your best attire?

speaker: MARULLUS
line: And do you now cull out a holiday?

speaker: MARULLUS
line: And do you now strew flowers in his way

speaker: MARULLUS
line: That comes in triumph over Pompey's blood? Be gone!

speaker: MARULLUS
line: Run to your houses, fall upon your knees,

speaker: MARULLUS
line: Pray to the gods to intermit the plague

speaker: MARULLUS
line: That needs must light on this ingratitude.

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: Go, go, good countrymen, and, for this fault,

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: Assemble all the poor men of your sort;

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: Draw them to Tiber banks, and weep your tears

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: Into the channel, till the lowest stream

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: Do kiss the most exalted shores of all.

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: See whether their basest metal be not moved;

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: They vanish tongue-tied in their guiltiness.

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: Go you down that way towards the Capitol;

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: This way will I disrobe the images,

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: If you do find them deck'd with ceremonies.

speaker: MARULLUS
line: May we do so?

speaker: MARULLUS
line: You know it is the feast of Lupercal.

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: It is no matter; let no images

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: Be hung with Caesar's trophies. I'll about,

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: And drive away the vulgar from the streets:

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: So do you too, where you perceive them thick.

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: These growing feathers pluck'd from Caesar's wing

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: Will make him fly an ordinary pitch,

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: Who else would soar above the view of men

speaker: FLAVIUS
line: And keep us all in servile fearfulness.

speaker: CAESAR
line: Calpurnia!

speaker: CASCA
line: Peace, ho! Caesar speaks.

speaker: CAESAR
line: Calpurnia!

speaker: CALPURNIA
line: Here, my lord.

speaker: CAESAR
line: Stand you directly in Antonius' way,

speaker: CAESAR
line: When he doth run his course. Antonius!

speaker: ANTONY
line: Caesar, my lord?

speaker: CAESAR
line: Forget not, in your speed, Antonius,

speaker: CAESAR
line: To touch Calpurnia; for our elders say,

speaker: CAESAR
line: The barren, touched in this holy chase,

speaker: CAESAR
line: Shake off their sterile curse.

speaker: ANTONY
line: I shall remember:

speaker: ANTONY
line: When Caesar says 'do this,' it is perform'd.

speaker: CAESAR
line: Set on; and leave no ceremony out.

speaker: Soothsayer
line: Caesar!

speaker: CAESAR
line: Ha! who calls?

speaker: CASCA
line: Bid every noise be still: peace yet again!

speaker: CAESAR
line: Who is it in the press that calls on me?

speaker: CAESAR
line: I hear a tongue, shriller than all the music,

speaker: CAESAR
line: Cry 'Caesar!' Speak; Caesar is turn'd to hear.

speaker: Soothsayer
line: Beware the ides of March.

speaker: CAESAR
line: What man is that?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: A soothsayer bids you beware the ides of March.

speaker: CAESAR
line: Set him before me; let me see his face.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Fellow, come from the throng; look upon Caesar.

speaker: CAESAR
line: What say'st thou to me now? speak once again.

speaker: Soothsayer
line: Beware the ides of March.

speaker: CAESAR
line: He is a dreamer; let us leave him: pass.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Will you go see the order of the course?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Not I.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: I pray you, do.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I am not gamesome: I do lack some part

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Of that quick spirit that is in Antony.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Let me not hinder, Cassius, your desires;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I'll leave you.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Brutus, I do observe you now of late:

speaker: CASSIUS
line: I have not from your eyes that gentleness

speaker: CASSIUS
line: And show of love as I was wont to have:

speaker: CASSIUS
line: You bear too stubborn and too strange a hand

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Over your friend that loves you.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Cassius,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Be not deceived: if I have veil'd my look,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I turn the trouble of my countenance

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Merely upon myself. Vexed I am

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Of late with passions of some difference,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Conceptions only proper to myself,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Which give some soil perhaps to my behaviors;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: But let not therefore my good friends be grieved--

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Among which number, Cassius, be you one--

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Nor construe any further my neglect,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Than that poor Brutus, with himself at war,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Forgets the shows of love to other men.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Then, Brutus, I have much mistook your passion;

speaker: CASSIUS
line: By means whereof this breast of mine hath buried

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Thoughts of great value, worthy cogitations.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Tell me, good Brutus, can you see your face?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: No, Cassius; for the eye sees not itself,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: But by reflection, by some other things.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: 'Tis just:

speaker: CASSIUS
line: And it is very much lamented, Brutus,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: That you have no such mirrors as will turn

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Your hidden worthiness into your eye,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: That you might see your shadow. I have heard,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Where many of the best respect in Rome,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Except immortal Caesar, speaking of Brutus

speaker: CASSIUS
line: And groaning underneath this age's yoke,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Have wish'd that noble Brutus had his eyes.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Into what dangers would you lead me, Cassius,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: That you would have me seek into myself

speaker: BRUTUS
line: For that which is not in me?

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Therefore, good Brutus, be prepared to hear:

speaker: CASSIUS
line: And since you know you cannot see yourself

speaker: CASSIUS
line: So well as by reflection, I, your glass,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Will modestly discover to yourself

speaker: CASSIUS
line: That of yourself which you yet know not of.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: And be not jealous on me, gentle Brutus:

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Were I a common laugher, or did use

speaker: CASSIUS
line: To stale with ordinary oaths my love

speaker: CASSIUS
line: To every new protester; if you know

speaker: CASSIUS
line: That I do fawn on men and hug them hard

speaker: CASSIUS
line: And after scandal them, or if you know

speaker: CASSIUS
line: That I profess myself in banqueting

speaker: CASSIUS
line: To all the rout, then hold me dangerous.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: What means this shouting? I do fear, the people

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Choose Caesar for their king.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Ay, do you fear it?

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Then must I think you would not have it so.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I would not, Cassius; yet I love him well.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: But wherefore do you hold me here so long?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: What is it that you would impart to me?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: If it be aught toward the general good,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Set honour in one eye and death i' the other,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: And I will look on both indifferently,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: For let the gods so speed me as I love

speaker: BRUTUS
line: The name of honour more than I fear death.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: I know that virtue to be in you, Brutus,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: As well as I do know your outward favour.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Well, honour is the subject of my story.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: I cannot tell what you and other men

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Think of this life; but, for my single self,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: I had as lief not be as live to be

speaker: CASSIUS
line: In awe of such a thing as I myself.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: I was born free as Caesar; so were you:

speaker: CASSIUS
line: We both have fed as well, and we can both

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Endure the winter's cold as well as he:

speaker: CASSIUS
line: For once, upon a raw and gusty day,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: The troubled Tiber chafing with her shores,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Caesar said to me 'Darest thou, Cassius, now

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Leap in with me into this angry flood,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: And swim to yonder point?' Upon the word,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Accoutred as I was, I plunged in

speaker: CASSIUS
line: And bade him follow; so indeed he did.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: The torrent roar'd, and we did buffet it

speaker: CASSIUS
line: With lusty sinews, throwing it aside

speaker: CASSIUS
line: And stemming it with hearts of controversy;

speaker: CASSIUS
line: But ere we could arrive the point proposed,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Caesar cried 'Help me, Cassius, or I sink!'

speaker: CASSIUS
line: I, as Aeneas, our great ancestor,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Did from the flames of Troy upon his shoulder

speaker: CASSIUS
line: The old Anchises bear, so from the waves of Tiber

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Did I the tired Caesar. And this man

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Is now become a god, and Cassius is

speaker: CASSIUS
line: A wretched creature and must bend his body,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: If Caesar carelessly but nod on him.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: He had a fever when he was in Spain,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: And when the fit was on him, I did mark

speaker: CASSIUS
line: How he did shake: 'tis true, this god did shake;

speaker: CASSIUS
line: His coward lips did from their colour fly,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: And that same eye whose bend doth awe the world

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Did lose his lustre: I did hear him groan:

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Ay, and that tongue of his that bade the Romans

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Mark him and write his speeches in their books,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Alas, it cried 'Give me some drink, Titinius,'

speaker: CASSIUS
line: As a sick girl. Ye gods, it doth amaze me

speaker: CASSIUS
line: A man of such a feeble temper should

speaker: CASSIUS
line: So get the start of the majestic world

speaker: CASSIUS
line: And bear the palm alone.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Another general shout!

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I do believe that these applauses are

speaker: BRUTUS
line: For some new honours that are heap'd on Caesar.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Why, man, he doth bestride the narrow world

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Like a Colossus, and we petty men

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Walk under his huge legs and peep about

speaker: CASSIUS
line: To find ourselves dishonourable graves.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Men at some time are masters of their fates:

speaker: CASSIUS
line: The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: But in ourselves, that we are underlings.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Brutus and Caesar: what should be in that 'Caesar'?

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Why should that name be sounded more than yours?

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Write them together, yours is as fair a name;

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Sound them, it doth become the mouth as well;

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Weigh them, it is as heavy; conjure with 'em,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Brutus will start a spirit as soon as Caesar.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Now, in the names of all the gods at once,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Upon what meat doth this our Caesar feed,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: That he is grown so great? Age, thou art shamed!

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Rome, thou hast lost the breed of noble bloods!

speaker: CASSIUS
line: When went there by an age, since the great flood,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: But it was famed with more than with one man?

speaker: CASSIUS
line: When could they say till now, that talk'd of Rome,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: That her wide walls encompass'd but one man?

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Now is it Rome indeed and room enough,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: When there is in it but one only man.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: O, you and I have heard our fathers say,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: There was a Brutus once that would have brook'd

speaker: CASSIUS
line: The eternal devil to keep his state in Rome

speaker: CASSIUS
line: As easily as a king.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: That you do love me, I am nothing jealous;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: What you would work me to, I have some aim:

speaker: BRUTUS
line: How I have thought of this and of these times,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I shall recount hereafter; for this present,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I would not, so with love I might entreat you,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Be any further moved. What you have said

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I will consider; what you have to say

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I will with patience hear, and find a time

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Both meet to hear and answer such high things.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Till then, my noble friend, chew upon this:

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Brutus had rather be a villager

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Than to repute himself a son of Rome

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Under these hard conditions as this time

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Is like to lay upon us.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: I am glad that my weak words

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Have struck but thus much show of fire from Brutus.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: The games are done and Caesar is returning.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: As they pass by, pluck Casca by the sleeve;

speaker: CASSIUS
line: And he will, after his sour fashion, tell you

speaker: CASSIUS
line: What hath proceeded worthy note to-day.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I will do so. But, look you, Cassius,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: The angry spot doth glow on Caesar's brow,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: And all the rest look like a chidden train:

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Calpurnia's cheek is pale; and Cicero

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Looks with such ferret and such fiery eyes

speaker: BRUTUS
line: As we have seen him in the Capitol,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Being cross'd in conference by some senators.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Casca will tell us what the matter is.

speaker: CAESAR
line: Antonius!

speaker: ANTONY
line: Caesar?

speaker: CAESAR
line: Let me have men about me that are fat;

speaker: CAESAR
line: Sleek-headed men and such as sleep o' nights:

speaker: CAESAR
line: Yond Cassius has a lean and hungry look;

speaker: CAESAR
line: He thinks too much: such men are dangerous.

speaker: ANTONY
line: Fear him not, Caesar; he's not dangerous;

speaker: ANTONY
line: He is a noble Roman and well given.

speaker: CAESAR
line: Would he were fatter! But I fear him not:

speaker: CAESAR
line: Yet if my name were liable to fear,

speaker: CAESAR
line: I do not know the man I should avoid

speaker: CAESAR
line: So soon as that spare Cassius. He reads much;

speaker: CAESAR
line: He is a great observer and he looks

speaker: CAESAR
line: Quite through the deeds of men: he loves no plays,

speaker: CAESAR
line: As thou dost, Antony; he hears no music;

speaker: CAESAR
line: Seldom he smiles, and smiles in such a sort

speaker: CAESAR
line: As if he mock'd himself and scorn'd his spirit

speaker: CAESAR
line: That could be moved to smile at any thing.

speaker: CAESAR
line: Such men as he be never at heart's ease

speaker: CAESAR
line: Whiles they behold a greater than themselves,

speaker: CAESAR
line: And therefore are they very dangerous.

speaker: CAESAR
line: I rather tell thee what is to be fear'd

speaker: CAESAR
line: Than what I fear; for always I am Caesar.

speaker: CAESAR
line: Come on my right hand, for this ear is deaf,

speaker: CAESAR
line: And tell me truly what thou think'st of him.

speaker: CASCA
line: You pull'd me by the cloak; would you speak with me?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Ay, Casca; tell us what hath chanced to-day,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: That Caesar looks so sad.

speaker: CASCA
line: Why, you were with him, were you not?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I should not then ask Casca what had chanced.

speaker: CASCA
line: Why, there was a crown offered him: and being

speaker: CASCA
line: offered him, he put it by with the back of his hand,

speaker: CASCA
line: thus; and then the people fell a-shouting.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: What was the second noise for?

speaker: CASCA
line: Why, for that too.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: They shouted thrice: what was the last cry for?

speaker: CASCA
line: Why, for that too.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Was the crown offered him thrice?

speaker: CASCA
line: Ay, marry, was't, and he put it by thrice, every

speaker: CASCA
line: time gentler than other, and at every putting-by

speaker: CASCA
line: mine honest neighbours shouted.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Who offered him the crown?

speaker: CASCA
line: Why, Antony.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Tell us the manner of it, gentle Casca.

speaker: CASCA
line: I can as well be hanged as tell the manner of it:

speaker: CASCA
line: it was mere foolery; I did not mark it. I saw Mark

speaker: CASCA
line: Antony offer him a crown;--yet 'twas not a crown

speaker: CASCA
line: neither, 'twas one of these coronets;--and, as I told

speaker: CASCA
line: you, he put it by once: but, for all that, to my

speaker: CASCA
line: thinking, he would fain have had it. Then he

speaker: CASCA
line: offered it to him again; then he put it by again:

speaker: CASCA
line: but, to my thinking, he was very loath to lay his

speaker: CASCA
line: fingers off it. And then he offered it the third

speaker: CASCA
line: time; he put it the third time by: and still as he

speaker: CASCA
line: refused it, the rabblement hooted and clapped their

speaker: CASCA
line: chapped hands and threw up their sweaty night-caps

speaker: CASCA
line: and uttered such a deal of stinking breath because

speaker: CASCA
line: Caesar refused the crown that it had almost choked

speaker: CASCA
line: Caesar; for he swounded and fell down at it: and

speaker: CASCA
line: for mine own part, I durst not laugh, for fear of

speaker: CASCA
line: opening my lips and receiving the bad air.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: But, soft, I pray you: what, did Caesar swound?

speaker: CASCA
line: He fell down in the market-place, and foamed at

speaker: CASCA
line: mouth, and was speechless.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: 'Tis very like: he hath the failing sickness.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: No, Caesar hath it not; but you and I,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: And honest Casca, we have the falling sickness.

speaker: CASCA
line: I know not what you mean by that; but, I am sure,

speaker: CASCA
line: Caesar fell down. If the tag-rag people did not

speaker: CASCA
line: clap him and hiss him, according as he pleased and

speaker: CASCA
line: displeased them, as they use to do the players in

speaker: CASCA
line: the theatre, I am no true man.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: What said he when he came unto himself?

speaker: CASCA
line: Marry, before he fell down, when he perceived the

speaker: CASCA
line: common herd was glad he refused the crown, he

speaker: CASCA
line: plucked me ope his doublet and offered them his

speaker: CASCA
line: throat to cut. An I had been a man of any

speaker: CASCA
line: occupation, if I would not have taken him at a word,

speaker: CASCA
line: I would I might go to hell among the rogues. And so

speaker: CASCA
line: he fell. When he came to himself again, he said,

speaker: CASCA
line: If he had done or said any thing amiss, he desired

speaker: CASCA
line: their worships to think it was his infirmity. Three

speaker: CASCA
line: or four wenches, where I stood, cried 'Alas, good

speaker: CASCA
line: soul!' and forgave him with all their hearts: but

speaker: CASCA
line: there's no heed to be taken of them; if Caesar had

speaker: CASCA
line: stabbed their mothers, they would have done no less.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: And after that, he came, thus sad, away?

speaker: CASCA
line: Ay.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Did Cicero say any thing?

speaker: CASCA
line: Ay, he spoke Greek.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: To what effect?

speaker: CASCA
line: Nay, an I tell you that, Ill ne'er look you i' the

speaker: CASCA
line: face again: but those that understood him smiled at

speaker: CASCA
line: one another and shook their heads; but, for mine own

speaker: CASCA
line: part, it was Greek to me. I could tell you more

speaker: CASCA

line: 'Brutus, thou sleep'st: awake, and see thyself.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Shall Rome, &c. Speak, strike, redress!

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Brutus, thou sleep'st: awake!'

speaker: BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS
line: 'Shall Rome, &c.' Thus must I piece it out:

speaker: BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS
line: 'Speak, strike, redress!' Am I entreated

speaker: LUCIUS
line: Sir, March is wasted fourteen days.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: 'Tis good. Go to the gate; somebody knocks.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Since Cassius first did whet me against Caesar,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I have not slept.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Between the acting of a dreadful thing

speaker: BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS
line: The Genius and the mortal instruments

speaker: BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS

speaker: LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS

speaker: BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Where wilt thou find a cavern dark enough

line: To mask thy monstrous visage? Seek none, conspiracy;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Hide it in smiles and affability:

speaker: BRUTUS
line: For if thou path, thy native semblance on,

speaker: BRUTUS

speaker: CASSIUS

speaker: CASSIUS

line: I have been up this hour, awake all night.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Know I these men that come along with you?

speaker: CASSIUS

speaker: CASSIUS

speaker: BRUTUS

speaker: CAESAR

speaker: CALPURNIA

speaker: CALPURNIA

speaker: CAESAR

line: When beggars die, there are no comets seen;

line: The gods do this in shame of cowardice:

speaker: CAESAR

speaker: CALPURNIA

line: Caesar, all hail! good morrow, worthy Caesar:

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: I come to fetch you to the senate-house.

speaker: CAESAR
line: And you are come in very happy time,

speaker: CAESAR
line: To bear my greeting to the senators

speaker: CAESAR
line: And tell them that I will not come to-day:

speaker: CAESAR
line: Cannot, is false, and that I dare not, falser:

speaker: CAESAR
line: I will not come to-day: tell them so, Decius.

speaker: CALPURNIA
line: Say he is sick.

speaker: CAESAR
line: Shall Caesar send a lie?

speaker: CAESAR
line: Have I in conquest stretch'd mine arm so far,

speaker: CAESAR
line: To be afraid to tell graybeards the truth?

speaker: CAESAR
line: Decius, go tell them Caesar will not come.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cause,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: Lest I be laugh'd at when I tell them so.

speaker: CAESAR
line: The cause is in my will: I will not come;

speaker: CAESAR
line: That is enough to satisfy the senate.

speaker: CAESAR
line: But for your private satisfaction,

speaker: CAESAR
line: Because I love you, I will let you know:

speaker: CAESAR
line: Calpurnia here, my wife, stays me at home:

speaker: CAESAR
line: She dreamt to-night she saw my statua,

speaker: CAESAR
line: Which, like a fountain with an hundred spouts,

speaker: CAESAR
line: Did run pure blood: and many lusty Romans

speaker: CAESAR
line: Came smiling, and did bathe their hands in it:

speaker: CAESAR
line: And these does she apply for warnings, and portents,

speaker: CAESAR
line: And evils imminent; and on her knee

speaker: CAESAR
line: Hath begg'd that I will stay at home to-day.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: This dream is all amiss interpreted;

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: It was a vision fair and fortunate:

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: Your statue spouting blood in many pipes,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: In which so many smiling Romans bathed,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: Signifies that from you great Rome shall suck

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: Reviving blood, and that great men shall press

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: For tinctures, stains, relics and cognizance.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: This by Calpurnia's dream is signified.

speaker: CAESAR
line: And this way have you well expounded it.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: I have, when you have heard what I can say:

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: And know it now: the senate have concluded

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: To give this day a crown to mighty Caesar.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: If you shall send them word you will not come,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: Their minds may change. Besides, it were a mock

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: Apt to be render'd, for some one to say

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: 'Break up the senate till another time,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: When Caesar's wife shall meet with better dreams.'

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: If Caesar hide himself, shall they not whisper

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: 'Lo, Caesar is afraid'?

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: Pardon me, Caesar; for my dear dear love

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: To our proceeding bids me tell you this;

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: And reason to my love is liable.

speaker: CAESAR
line: How foolish do your fears seem now, Calpurnia!

speaker: CAESAR
line: I am ashamed I did yield to them.

speaker: CAESAR
line: Give me my robe, for I will go.

speaker: CAESAR
line: And look where Publius is come to fetch me.

speaker: PUBLIUS
line: Good morrow, Caesar.

speaker: CAESAR
line: Welcome, Publius.

speaker: CAESAR
line: What, Brutus, are you stirr'd so early too?

speaker: CAESAR
line: Good morrow, Casca. Caius Ligarius,

speaker: CAESAR
line: Caesar was ne'er so much your enemy

speaker: CAESAR
line: As that same ague which hath made you lean.

speaker: CAESAR
line: What is 't o'clock?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Caesar, 'tis strucken eight.

speaker: CAESAR
line: I thank you for your pains and courtesy.

speaker: CAESAR
line: See! Antony, that revels long o' nights,

speaker: CAESAR
line: Is notwithstanding up. Good morrow, Antony.

speaker: ANTONY
line: So to most noble Caesar.

speaker: CAESAR
line: Bid them prepare within:

speaker: CAESAR
line: I am to blame to be thus waited for.

speaker: CAESAR
line: Now, Cinna: now, Metellus: what, Trebonius!

speaker: CAESAR
line: I have an hour's talk in store for you;

speaker: CAESAR
line: Remember that you call on me to-day:

speaker: CAESAR
line: Be near me, that I may remember you.

speaker: TREBONIUS
line: Caesar, I will:

speaker: TREBONIUS
line: and so near will I be,

speaker: TREBONIUS
line: That your best friends shall wish I had been further.

speaker: CAESAR
line: Good friends, go in, and taste some wine with me;

speaker: CAESAR
line: And we, like friends, will straightway go together.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Aside  That every like is not the same, O Caesar,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: The heart of Brutus yearns to think upon!

scene: SCENE III.  A street near the Capitol.
speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
line: 'Caesar, beware of Brutus; take heed of Cassius;

scene: SCENE III.  A street near the Capitol.
speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
line: come not near Casca; have an eye to Cinna, trust not

scene: SCENE III.  A street near the Capitol.
speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
line: Trebonius: mark well Metellus Cimber: Decius Brutus

scene: SCENE III.  A street near the Capitol.
speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
line: loves thee not: thou hast wronged Caius Ligarius.

scene: SCENE III.  A street near the Capitol.
speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
line: There is but one mind in all these men, and it is

scene: SCENE III.  A street near the Capitol.
speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
line: bent against Caesar. If thou beest not immortal,

scene: SCENE III.  A street near the Capitol.
speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
line: look about you: security gives way to conspiracy.

scene: SCENE III.  A street near the Capitol.
speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
line: The mighty gods defend thee! Thy lover,

scene: SCENE III.  A street near the Capitol.
speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
line: 'ARTEMIDORUS.'

scene: SCENE III.  A street near the Capitol.
speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
line: Here will I stand till Caesar pass along,

scene: SCENE III.  A street near the Capitol.
speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
line: And as a suitor will I give him this.

scene: SCENE III.  A street near the Capitol.
speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
line: My heart laments that virtue cannot live

scene: SCENE III.  A street near the Capitol.
speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
line: Out of the teeth of emulation.

scene: SCENE III.  A street near the Capitol.
speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
line: If thou read this, O Caesar, thou mayst live;

scene: SCENE III.  A street near the Capitol.
speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
line: If not, the Fates with traitors do contrive.

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: I prithee, boy, run to the senate-house;

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: Stay not to answer me, but get thee gone:

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: Why dost thou stay?

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: LUCIUS
line: To know my errand, madam.

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: I would have had thee there, and here again,

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: Ere I can tell thee what thou shouldst do there.

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: O constancy, be strong upon my side,

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: Set a huge mountain 'tween my heart and tongue!

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: I have a man's mind, but a woman's might.

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: How hard it is for women to keep counsel!

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: Art thou here yet?

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: LUCIUS
line: Madam, what should I do?

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: LUCIUS
line: Run to the Capitol, and nothing else?

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: LUCIUS
line: And so return to you, and nothing else?

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: Yes, bring me word, boy, if thy lord look well,

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: For he went sickly forth: and take good note

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: What Caesar doth, what suitors press to him.

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: Hark, boy! what noise is that?

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: LUCIUS
line: I hear none, madam.

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: Prithee, listen well;

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: I heard a bustling rumour, like a fray,

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: And the wind brings it from the Capitol.

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: LUCIUS
line: Sooth, madam, I hear nothing.

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: Come hither, fellow: which way hast thou been?

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: Soothsayer
line: At mine own house, good lady.

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: What is't o'clock?

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: Soothsayer
line: About the ninth hour, lady.

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: Is Caesar yet gone to the Capitol?

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: Soothsayer
line: Madam, not yet: I go to take my stand,

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: Soothsayer
line: To see him pass on to the Capitol.

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: Thou hast some suit to Caesar, hast thou not?

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: Soothsayer
line: That I have, lady: if it will please Caesar

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: Soothsayer
line: To be so good to Caesar as to hear me,

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: Soothsayer
line: I shall beseech him to befriend himself.

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: Why, know'st thou any harm's intended towards him?

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: Soothsayer
line: None that I know will be, much that I fear may chance.

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: Soothsayer
line: Good morrow to you. Here the street is narrow:

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: Soothsayer
line: The throng that follows Caesar at the heels,

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: Soothsayer
line: Of senators, of praetors, common suitors,

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: Soothsayer
line: Will crowd a feeble man almost to death:

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: Soothsayer
line: I'll get me to a place more void, and there

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: Soothsayer
line: Speak to great Caesar as he comes along.

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: I must go in. Ay me, how weak a thing

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: The heart of woman is! O Brutus,

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: The heavens speed thee in thine enterprise!

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: Sure, the boy heard me: Brutus hath a suit

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: That Caesar will not grant. O, I grow faint.

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: Run, Lucius, and commend me to my lord;

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: Say I am merry: come to me again,

scene: SCENE IV.  Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.
speaker: PORTIA
line: And bring me word what he doth say to thee.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: To the Soothsayer  The ides of March are come.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: Soothsayer
line: Ay, Caesar; but not gone.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
line: Hail, Caesar! read this schedule.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: Trebonius doth desire you to o'erread,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: At your best leisure, this his humble suit.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
line: O Caesar, read mine first; for mine's a suit

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
line: That touches Caesar nearer: read it, great Caesar.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: What touches us ourself shall be last served.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
line: Delay not, Caesar; read it instantly.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: What, is the fellow mad?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: PUBLIUS
line: Sirrah, give place.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: What, urge you your petitions in the street?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Come to the Capitol.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: POPILIUS
line: I wish your enterprise to-day may thrive.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: What enterprise, Popilius?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: POPILIUS
line: Fare you well.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: What said Popilius Lena?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: He wish'd to-day our enterprise might thrive.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: I fear our purpose is discovered.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Look, how he makes to Caesar; mark him.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Casca, be sudden, for we fear prevention.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Brutus, what shall be done? If this be known,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Cassius or Caesar never shall turn back,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: For I will slay myself.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Cassius, be constant:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Popilius Lena speaks not of our purposes;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: For, look, he smiles, and Caesar doth not change.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Trebonius knows his time; for, look you, Brutus.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: He draws Mark Antony out of the way.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: Where is Metellus Cimber? Let him go,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: And presently prefer his suit to Caesar.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: He is address'd: press near and second him.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CINNA
line: Casca, you are the first that rears your hand.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: Are we all ready? What is now amiss

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: That Caesar and his senate must redress?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
line: Most high, most mighty, and most puissant Caesar,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
line: Metellus Cimber throws before thy seat

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
line: An humble heart,--

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: I must prevent thee, Cimber.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: These couchings and these lowly courtesies

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: Might fire the blood of ordinary men,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: And turn pre-ordinance and first decree

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: Into the law of children. Be not fond,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: To think that Caesar bears such rebel blood

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: That will be thaw'd from the true quality

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: With that which melteth fools; I mean, sweet words,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: Low-crooked court'sies and base spaniel-fawning.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: Thy brother by decree is banished:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: If thou dost bend and pray and fawn for him,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: I spurn thee like a cur out of my way.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: Know, Caesar doth not wrong, nor without cause

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: Will he be satisfied.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
line: Is there no voice more worthy than my own

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
line: To sound more sweetly in great Caesar's ear

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
line: For the repealing of my banish'd brother?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: I kiss thy hand, but not in flattery, Caesar;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Desiring thee that Publius Cimber may

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Have an immediate freedom of repeal.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: What, Brutus!

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Pardon, Caesar; Caesar, pardon:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: As low as to thy foot doth Cassius fall,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: To beg enfranchisement for Publius Cimber.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: I could be well moved, if I were as you:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: If I could pray to move, prayers would move me:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: But I am constant as the northern star,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Of whose true-fix'd and resting quality

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: There is no fellow in the firmament.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: The skies are painted with unnumber'd sparks,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: They are all fire and every one doth shine,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: But there's but one in all doth hold his place:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: So in the world; 'tis furnish'd well with men,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: And men are flesh and blood, and apprehensive;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Yet in the number I do know but one

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: That unassailable holds on his rank,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Unshaked of motion: and that I am he,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Let me a little show it, even in this;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: That I was constant Cimber should be banish'd,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: And constant do remain to keep him so.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CINNA
line: O Caesar,--

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: Hence! wilt thou lift up Olympus?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: Great Caesar,--

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: Doth not Brutus bootless kneel?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASCA
line: Speak, hands for me!

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CAESAR
line: Et tu, Brute! Then fall, Caesar.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CINNA
line: Liberty! Freedom! Tyranny is dead!

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CINNA
line: Run hence, proclaim, cry it about the streets.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Some to the common pulpits, and cry out

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: 'Liberty, freedom, and enfranchisement!'

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: People and senators, be not affrighted;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Fly not; stand stiff: ambition's debt is paid.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASCA
line: Go to the pulpit, Brutus.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: And Cassius too.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Where's Publius?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CINNA
line: Here, quite confounded with this mutiny.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
line: Stand fast together, lest some friend of Caesar's

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
line: Should chance--

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Talk not of standing. Publius, good cheer;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: There is no harm intended to your person,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Nor to no Roman else: so tell them, Publius.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: And leave us, Publius; lest that the people,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Rushing on us, should do your age some mischief.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Do so: and let no man abide this deed,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: But we the doers.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Where is Antony?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: TREBONIUS
line: Fled to his house amazed:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: TREBONIUS
line: Men, wives and children stare, cry out and run

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: TREBONIUS
line: As it were doomsday.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Fates, we will know your pleasures:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: That we shall die, we know; 'tis but the time

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: And drawing days out, that men stand upon.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Why, he that cuts off twenty years of life

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Cuts off so many years of fearing death.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Grant that, and then is death a benefit:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: So are we Caesar's friends, that have abridged

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: His time of fearing death. Stoop, Romans, stoop,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: And let us bathe our hands in Caesar's blood

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Up to the elbows, and besmear our swords:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Then walk we forth, even to the market-place,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: And, waving our red weapons o'er our heads,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Let's all cry 'Peace, freedom and liberty!'

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Stoop, then, and wash. How many ages hence

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Shall this our lofty scene be acted over

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: In states unborn and accents yet unknown!

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: How many times shall Caesar bleed in sport,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: That now on Pompey's basis lies along

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: No worthier than the dust!

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: So oft as that shall be,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: So often shall the knot of us be call'd

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: The men that gave their country liberty.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
line: What, shall we forth?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Ay, every man away:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Brutus shall lead; and we will grace his heels

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: With the most boldest and best hearts of Rome.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Soft! who comes here? A friend of Antony's.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: Servant
line: Thus, Brutus, did my master bid me kneel:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: Servant
line: Thus did Mark Antony bid me fall down;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: Servant
line: And, being prostrate, thus he bade me say:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: Servant
line: Brutus is noble, wise, valiant, and honest;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: Servant
line: Caesar was mighty, bold, royal, and loving:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: Servant
line: Say I love Brutus, and I honour him;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: Servant
line: Say I fear'd Caesar, honour'd him and loved him.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: Servant
line: If Brutus will vouchsafe that Antony

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: Servant
line: May safely come to him, and be resolved

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: Servant
line: How Caesar hath deserved to lie in death,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: Servant
line: Mark Antony shall not love Caesar dead

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: Servant
line: So well as Brutus living; but will follow

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: Servant
line: The fortunes and affairs of noble Brutus

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: Servant
line: Thorough the hazards of this untrod state

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: Servant
line: With all true faith. So says my master Antony.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Thy master is a wise and valiant Roman;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: I never thought him worse.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Tell him, so please him come unto this place,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: He shall be satisfied; and, by my honour,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Depart untouch'd.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: Servant
line: I'll fetch him presently.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: I know that we shall have him well to friend.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: I wish we may: but yet have I a mind

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: That fears him much; and my misgiving still

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Falls shrewdly to the purpose.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: But here comes Antony.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Welcome, Mark Antony.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: O mighty Caesar! dost thou lie so low?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Are all thy conquests, glories, triumphs, spoils,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Shrunk to this little measure? Fare thee well.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: I know not, gentlemen, what you intend,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Who else must be let blood, who else is rank:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: If I myself, there is no hour so fit

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: As Caesar's death hour, nor no instrument

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Of half that worth as those your swords, made rich

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: With the most noble blood of all this world.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: I do beseech ye, if you bear me hard,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Now, whilst your purpled hands do reek and smoke,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Fulfil your pleasure. Live a thousand years,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: I shall not find myself so apt to die:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: No place will please me so, no mean of death,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: As here by Caesar, and by you cut off,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: The choice and master spirits of this age.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: O Antony, beg not your death of us.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Though now we must appear bloody and cruel,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: As, by our hands and this our present act,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: You see we do, yet see you but our hands

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: And this the bleeding business they have done:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Our hearts you see not; they are pitiful;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: And pity to the general wrong of Rome--

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: As fire drives out fire, so pity pity--

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Hath done this deed on Caesar. For your part,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: To you our swords have leaden points, Mark Antony:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Our arms, in strength of malice, and our hearts

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Of brothers' temper, do receive you in

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: With all kind love, good thoughts, and reverence.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Your voice shall be as strong as any man's

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: In the disposing of new dignities.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Only be patient till we have appeased

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: The multitude, beside themselves with fear,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: And then we will deliver you the cause,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Why I, that did love Caesar when I struck him,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Have thus proceeded.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: I doubt not of your wisdom.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Let each man render me his bloody hand:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: First, Marcus Brutus, will I shake with you;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Next, Caius Cassius, do I take your hand;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Now, Decius Brutus, yours: now yours, Metellus;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Yours, Cinna; and, my valiant Casca, yours;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Though last, not last in love, yours, good Trebonius.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Gentlemen all,--alas, what shall I say?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: My credit now stands on such slippery ground,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: That one of two bad ways you must conceit me,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Either a coward or a flatterer.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: That I did love thee, Caesar, O, 'tis true:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: If then thy spirit look upon us now,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Shall it not grieve thee dearer than thy death,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: To see thy thy Anthony making his peace,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Shaking the bloody fingers of thy foes,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Most noble! in the presence of thy corse?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Had I as many eyes as thou hast wounds,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Weeping as fast as they stream forth thy blood,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: It would become me better than to close

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: In terms of friendship with thine enemies.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Pardon me, Julius! Here wast thou bay'd, brave hart;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Here didst thou fall; and here thy hunters stand,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Sign'd in thy spoil, and crimson'd in thy lethe.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: O world, thou wast the forest to this hart;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: And this, indeed, O world, the heart of thee.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: How like a deer, strucken by many princes,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Dost thou here lie!

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Mark Antony,--

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Pardon me, Caius Cassius:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: The enemies of Caesar shall say this;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Then, in a friend, it is cold modesty.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: I blame you not for praising Caesar so;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: But what compact mean you to have with us?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Will you be prick'd in number of our friends;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Or shall we on, and not depend on you?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Therefore I took your hands, but was, indeed,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Sway'd from the point, by looking down on Caesar.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Friends am I with you all and love you all,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Upon this hope, that you shall give me reasons

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Why and wherein Caesar was dangerous.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Or else were this a savage spectacle:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Our reasons are so full of good regard

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: That were you, Antony, the son of Caesar,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: You should be satisfied.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: That's all I seek:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: And am moreover suitor that I may

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Produce his body to the market-place;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: And in the pulpit, as becomes a friend,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Speak in the order of his funeral.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: You shall, Mark Antony.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Brutus, a word with you.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: You know not what you do: do not consent

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: That Antony speak in his funeral:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Know you how much the people may be moved

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: By that which he will utter?

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: By your pardon;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: I will myself into the pulpit first,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: And show the reason of our Caesar's death:

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: What Antony shall speak, I will protest

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: He speaks by leave and by permission,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: And that we are contented Caesar shall

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Have all true rites and lawful ceremonies.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: It shall advantage more than do us wrong.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: I know not what may fall; I like it not.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Mark Antony, here, take you Caesar's body.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: You shall not in your funeral speech blame us,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: But speak all good you can devise of Caesar,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: And say you do't by our permission;

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Else shall you not have any hand at all

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: About his funeral: and you shall speak

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: In the same pulpit whereto I am going,

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.

scene: SCENE I.  Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: If there be any in this assembly, any dear friend of

line: Caesar's, to him I say, that Brutus' love to Caesar

speaker: BRUTUS
line: was no less than his. If then that friend demand

speaker: BRUTUS
line: why Brutus rose against Caesar, this is my answer:

speaker: BRUTUS
line: --Not that I loved Caesar less, but that I loved

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Rome more. Had you rather Caesar were living and

speaker: BRUTUS
line: die all slaves, than that Caesar were dead, to live

speaker: BRUTUS
line: all free men? As Caesar loved me, I weep for him;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: as he was fortunate, I rejoice at it; as he was

speaker: BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS
line: slew him. There is tears for his love; joy for his

speaker: BRUTUS
line: fortune; honour for his valour; and death for his

speaker: BRUTUS
line: ambition. Who is here so base that would be a

speaker: BRUTUS
line: bondman? If any, speak; for him have I offended.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Who is here so rude that would not be a Roman? If

speaker: BRUTUS
line: any, speak; for him have I offended. Who is here so

speaker: BRUTUS
line: vile that will not love his country? If any, speak;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: for him have I offended. I pause for a reply.

speaker: All
line: None, Brutus, none.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Then none have I offended. I have done no more to

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Caesar than you shall do to Brutus. The question of

speaker: BRUTUS
line: his death is enrolled in the Capitol; his glory not

speaker: BRUTUS
line: extenuated, wherein he was worthy, nor his offences

speaker: BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS
