line: Have not you love enough to bear with me,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: When that rash humour which my mother gave me

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Makes me forgetful?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Yes, Cassius; and, from henceforth,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: When you are over-earnest with your Brutus,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: He'll think your mother chides, and leave you so.

speaker: Poet
line: Within  Let me go in to see the generals;

speaker: Poet
line: There is some grudge between 'em, 'tis not meet

speaker: Poet
line: They be alone.

speaker: LUCILIUS
line: Within  You shall not come to them.

speaker: Poet
line: Within  Nothing but death shall stay me.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: How now! what's the matter?

speaker: Poet
line: For shame, you generals! what do you mean?

speaker: Poet
line: Love, and be friends, as two such men should be;

speaker: Poet
line: For I have seen more years, I'm sure, than ye.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Ha, ha! how vilely doth this cynic rhyme!

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Get you hence, sirrah; saucy fellow, hence!

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Bear with him, Brutus; 'tis his fashion.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I'll know his humour, when he knows his time:

speaker: BRUTUS
line: What should the wars do with these jigging fools?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Companion, hence!

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Away, away, be gone.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Lucilius and Titinius, bid the commanders

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Prepare to lodge their companies to-night.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: And come yourselves, and bring Messala with you

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Immediately to us.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Lucius, a bowl of wine!

speaker: CASSIUS
line: I did not think you could have been so angry.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: O Cassius, I am sick of many griefs.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Of your philosophy you make no use,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: If you give place to accidental evils.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: No man bears sorrow better. Portia is dead.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Ha! Portia!

speaker: BRUTUS
line: She is dead.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: How 'scaped I killing when I cross'd you so?

speaker: CASSIUS
line: O insupportable and touching loss!

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Upon what sickness?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Impatient of my absence,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: And grief that young Octavius with Mark Antony

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Have made themselves so strong:--for with her death

speaker: BRUTUS
line: That tidings came;--with this she fell distract,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: And, her attendants absent, swallow'd fire.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: And died so?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Even so.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: O ye immortal gods!

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Speak no more of her. Give me a bowl of wine.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: In this I bury all unkindness, Cassius.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: My heart is thirsty for that noble pledge.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Fill, Lucius, till the wine o'erswell the cup;

speaker: CASSIUS
line: I cannot drink too much of Brutus' love.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Come in, Titinius!

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Welcome, good Messala.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Now sit we close about this taper here,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: And call in question our necessities.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Portia, art thou gone?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: No more, I pray you.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Messala, I have here received letters,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: That young Octavius and Mark Antony

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Come down upon us with a mighty power,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Bending their expedition toward Philippi.

speaker: MESSALA
line: Myself have letters of the selfsame tenor.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: With what addition?

speaker: MESSALA
line: That by proscription and bills of outlawry,

speaker: MESSALA
line: Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus,

speaker: MESSALA
line: Have put to death an hundred senators.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Therein our letters do not well agree;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Mine speak of seventy senators that died

speaker: BRUTUS
line: By their proscriptions, Cicero being one.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Cicero one!

speaker: MESSALA
line: Cicero is dead,

speaker: MESSALA
line: And by that order of proscription.

speaker: MESSALA
line: Had you your letters from your wife, my lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: No, Messala.

speaker: MESSALA
line: Nor nothing in your letters writ of her?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Nothing, Messala.

speaker: MESSALA
line: That, methinks, is strange.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Why ask you? hear you aught of her in yours?

speaker: MESSALA
line: No, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Now, as you are a Roman, tell me true.

speaker: MESSALA
line: Then like a Roman bear the truth I tell:

speaker: MESSALA
line: For certain she is dead, and by strange manner.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Why, farewell, Portia. We must die, Messala:

speaker: BRUTUS
line: With meditating that she must die once,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I have the patience to endure it now.

speaker: MESSALA
line: Even so great men great losses should endure.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: I have as much of this in art as you,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: But yet my nature could not bear it so.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Well, to our work alive. What do you think

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Of marching to Philippi presently?

speaker: CASSIUS
line: I do not think it good.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Your reason?

speaker: CASSIUS
line: This it is:

speaker: CASSIUS
line: 'Tis better that the enemy seek us:

speaker: CASSIUS
line: So shall he waste his means, weary his soldiers,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Doing himself offence; whilst we, lying still,

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Are full of rest, defense, and nimbleness.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Good reasons must, of force, give place to better.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: The people 'twixt Philippi and this ground

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Do stand but in a forced affection;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: For they have grudged us contribution:

speaker: BRUTUS
line: The enemy, marching along by them,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: By them shall make a fuller number up,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Come on refresh'd, new-added, and encouraged;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: From which advantage shall we cut him off,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: If at Philippi we do face him there,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: These people at our back.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Hear me, good brother.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Under your pardon. You must note beside,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: That we have tried the utmost of our friends,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Our legions are brim-full, our cause is ripe:

speaker: BRUTUS
line: The enemy increaseth every day;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: We, at the height, are ready to decline.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: There is a tide in the affairs of men,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Which, taken at the flood, leads on to fortune;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Omitted, all the voyage of their life

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Is bound in shallows and in miseries.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: On such a full sea are we now afloat;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: And we must take the current when it serves,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Or lose our ventures.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Then, with your will, go on;

speaker: CASSIUS
line: We'll along ourselves, and meet them at Philippi.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: The deep of night is crept upon our talk,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: And nature must obey necessity;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Which we will niggard with a little rest.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: There is no more to say?

speaker: CASSIUS
line: No more. Good night:

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Early to-morrow will we rise, and hence.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Lucius!

speaker: BRUTUS
line: My gown.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Farewell, good Messala:

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Good night, Titinius. Noble, noble Cassius,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Good night, and good repose.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: O my dear brother!

speaker: CASSIUS
line: This was an ill beginning of the night:

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Never come such division 'tween our souls!

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Let it not, Brutus.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Every thing is well.

speaker: CASSIUS
line: Good night, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Good night, good brother.

speaker: TITINIUS
line: Good night, Lord Brutus.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Farewell, every one.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Give me the gown. Where is thy instrument?

speaker: LUCIUS
line: Here in the tent.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: What, thou speak'st drowsily?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Poor knave, I blame thee not; thou art o'er-watch'd.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Call Claudius and some other of my men:

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I'll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.

speaker: LUCIUS
line: Varro and Claudius!

speaker: VARRO
line: Calls my lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I pray you, sirs, lie in my tent and sleep;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: It may be I shall raise you by and by

speaker: BRUTUS
line: On business to my brother Cassius.

speaker: VARRO
line: So please you, we will stand and watch your pleasure.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I will not have it so: lie down, good sirs;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: It may be I shall otherwise bethink me.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Look, Lucius, here's the book I sought for so;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I put it in the pocket of my gown.

speaker: LUCIUS
line: I was sure your lordship did not give it me.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Bear with me, good boy, I am much forgetful.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Canst thou hold up thy heavy eyes awhile,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: And touch thy instrument a strain or two?

speaker: LUCIUS
line: Ay, my lord, an't please you.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: It does, my boy:

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.

speaker: LUCIUS
line: It is my duty, sir.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I should not urge thy duty past thy might;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I know young bloods look for a time of rest.

speaker: LUCIUS
line: I have slept, my lord, already.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: It was well done; and thou shalt sleep again;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I will not hold thee long: if I do live,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I will be good to thee.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: This is a sleepy tune. O murderous slumber,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Lay'st thou thy leaden mace upon my boy,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: That plays thee music? Gentle knave, good night;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I will not do thee so much wrong to wake thee:

speaker: BRUTUS
line: If thou dost nod, thou break'st thy instrument;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I'll take it from thee; and, good boy, good night.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Let me see, let me see; is not the leaf turn'd down

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Where I left reading? Here it is, I think.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: How ill this taper burns! Ha! who comes here?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: I think it is the weakness of mine eyes

speaker: BRUTUS
line: That shapes this monstrous apparition.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: It comes upon me. Art thou any thing?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Art thou some god, some angel, or some devil,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: That makest my blood cold and my hair to stare?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Speak to me what thou art.

speaker: GHOST
line: Thy evil spirit, Brutus.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Why comest thou?

speaker: GHOST
line: To tell thee thou shalt see me at Philippi.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Well; then I shall see thee again?

speaker: GHOST
line: Ay, at Philippi.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Why, I will see thee at Philippi, then.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Now I have taken heart thou vanishest:

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Ill spirit, I would hold more talk with thee.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Boy, Lucius! Varro! Claudius! Sirs, awake! Claudius!

speaker: LUCIUS
line: The strings, my lord, are false.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: He thinks he still is at his instrument.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Lucius, awake!

speaker: LUCIUS
line: My lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Didst thou dream, Lucius, that thou so criedst out?

speaker: LUCIUS
line: My lord, I do not know that I did cry.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Yes, that thou didst: didst thou see any thing?

speaker: LUCIUS
line: Nothing, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Sleep again, Lucius. Sirrah Claudius!

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Fellow thou, awake!

speaker: VARRO
line: My lord?

speaker: CLAUDIUS
line: My lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Why did you so cry out, sirs, in your sleep?

speaker: VARRO
line: Did we, my lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Ay: saw you any thing?

speaker: VARRO
line: No, my lord, I saw nothing.

speaker: CLAUDIUS
line: Nor I, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Go and commend me to my brother Cassius;

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Bid him set on his powers betimes before,

speaker: BRUTUS
line: And we will follow.

speaker: VARRO
line: It shall be done, my lord.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: Now, Antony, our hopes are answered:

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: You said the enemy would not come down,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: But keep the hills and upper regions;

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: It proves not so: their battles are at hand;

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: They mean to warn us at Philippi here,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: Answering before we do demand of them.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Tut, I am in their bosoms, and I know

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Wherefore they do it: they could be content

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: To visit other places; and come down

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: With fearful bravery, thinking by this face

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: To fasten in our thoughts that they have courage;

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: But 'tis not so.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: Messenger
line: Prepare you, generals:

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: Messenger
line: The enemy comes on in gallant show;

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: Messenger
line: Their bloody sign of battle is hung out,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: Messenger
line: And something to be done immediately.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Octavius, lead your battle softly on,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Upon the left hand of the even field.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: Upon the right hand I; keep thou the left.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Why do you cross me in this exigent?

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: I do not cross you; but I will do so.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: They stand, and would have parley.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Stand fast, Titinius: we must out and talk.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: Mark Antony, shall we give sign of battle?

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: No, Caesar, we will answer on their charge.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Make forth; the generals would have some words.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: Stir not until the signal.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Words before blows: is it so, countrymen?

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: Not that we love words better, as you do.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Good words are better than bad strokes, Octavius.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: In your bad strokes, Brutus, you give good words:

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Witness the hole you made in Caesar's heart,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Crying 'Long live! hail, Caesar!'

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Antony,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: The posture of your blows are yet unknown;

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: But for your words, they rob the Hybla bees,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: And leave them honeyless.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Not stingless too.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: O, yes, and soundless too;

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: For you have stol'n their buzzing, Antony,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: And very wisely threat before you sting.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Villains, you did not so, when your vile daggers

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Hack'd one another in the sides of Caesar:

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: You show'd your teeth like apes, and fawn'd like hounds,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: And bow'd like bondmen, kissing Caesar's feet;

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Whilst damned Casca, like a cur, behind

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Struck Caesar on the neck. O you flatterers!

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Flatterers! Now, Brutus, thank yourself:

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: This tongue had not offended so to-day,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: If Cassius might have ruled.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: Come, come, the cause: if arguing make us sweat,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: The proof of it will turn to redder drops. Look;

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: I draw a sword against conspirators;

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: When think you that the sword goes up again?

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: Never, till Caesar's three and thirty wounds

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: Be well avenged; or till another Caesar

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: Have added slaughter to the sword of traitors.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Caesar, thou canst not die by traitors' hands,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Unless thou bring'st them with thee.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: So I hope;

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: I was not born to die on Brutus' sword.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: O, if thou wert the noblest of thy strain,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Young man, thou couldst not die more honourable.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: A peevish schoolboy, worthless of such honour,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Join'd with a masker and a reveller!

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Old Cassius still!

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: Come, Antony, away!

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: Defiance, traitors, hurl we in your teeth:

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: If you dare fight to-day, come to the field;

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: If not, when you have stomachs.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Why, now, blow wind, swell billow and swim bark!

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: The storm is up, and all is on the hazard.

speaker: BRUTUS
line: Ho, Lucilius! hark, a word with you.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: LUCILIUS
line: Standing forth My lord?

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Messala!

speaker: MESSALA
line: Standing forth  What says my general?

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Messala,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: This is my birth-day; as this very day

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Was Cassius born. Give me thy hand, Messala:

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Be thou my witness that against my will,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: As Pompey was, am I compell'd to set

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: You know that I held Epicurus strong

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: And his opinion: now I change my mind,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: And partly credit things that do presage.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Coming from Sardis, on our former ensign

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Two mighty eagles fell, and there they perch'd,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Gorging and feeding from our soldiers' hands;

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Who to Philippi here consorted us:

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: This morning are they fled away and gone;

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: And in their steads do ravens, crows and kites,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Fly o'er our heads and downward look on us,

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: As we were sickly prey: their shadows seem

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: A canopy most fatal, under which

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS
line: Our army lies, ready to give up the ghost.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: MESSALA

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS

speaker: CASSIUS

speaker: CASSIUS

speaker: CASSIUS

speaker: CASSIUS

speaker: CASSIUS

speaker: CASSIUS

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS

speaker: CASSIUS

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: BRUTUS

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.

speaker: BRUTUS

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: BRUTUS

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: CASSIUS

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.

scene: SCENE I.  The plains of Philippi.
speaker: BRUTUS

speaker: VOLUMNIUS
line: What says my lord?

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Why, this, Volumnius:

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: The ghost of Caesar hath appear'd to me

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Two several times by night; at Sardis once,

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: And, this last night, here in Philippi fields:

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: I know my hour is come.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: VOLUMNIUS
line: Not so, my lord.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Nay, I am sure it is, Volumnius.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Thou seest the world, Volumnius, how it goes;

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Our enemies have beat us to the pit:

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: It is more worthy to leap in ourselves,

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Than tarry till they push us. Good Volumnius,

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Thou know'st that we two went to school together:

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Even for that our love of old, I prithee,

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Hold thou my sword-hilts, whilst I run on it.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: VOLUMNIUS
line: That's not an office for a friend, my lord.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: CLITUS
line: Fly, fly, my lord; there is no tarrying here.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Farewell to you; and you; and you, Volumnius.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Strato, thou hast been all this while asleep;

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Farewell to thee too, Strato. Countrymen,

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: My heart doth joy that yet in all my life

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: I found no man but he was true to me.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: I shall have glory by this losing day

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: More than Octavius and Mark Antony

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: By this vile conquest shall attain unto.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: So fare you well at once; for Brutus' tongue

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Hath almost ended his life's history:

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Night hangs upon mine eyes; my bones would rest,

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: That have but labour'd to attain this hour.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: CLITUS
line: Fly, my lord, fly.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Hence! I will follow.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: I prithee, Strato, stay thou by thy lord:

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Thou art a fellow of a good respect;

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Thy life hath had some smatch of honour in it:

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Hold then my sword, and turn away thy face,

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: While I do run upon it. Wilt thou, Strato?

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: STRATO
line: Give me your hand first. Fare you well, my lord.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Farewell, good Strato.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: Caesar, now be still:

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: BRUTUS
line: I kill'd not thee with half so good a will.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: What man is that?

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: MESSALA
line: My master's man. Strato, where is thy master?

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: STRATO
line: Free from the bondage you are in, Messala:

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: STRATO
line: The conquerors can but make a fire of him;

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: STRATO
line: For Brutus only overcame himself,

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: STRATO
line: And no man else hath honour by his death.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: LUCILIUS
line: So Brutus should be found. I thank thee, Brutus,

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: LUCILIUS
line: That thou hast proved Lucilius' saying true.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: All that served Brutus, I will entertain them.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: Fellow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me?

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: STRATO
line: Ay, if Messala will prefer me to you.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: Do so, good Messala.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: MESSALA
line: How died my master, Strato?

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: STRATO
line: I held the sword, and he did run on it.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: MESSALA
line: Octavius, then take him to follow thee,

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: MESSALA
line: That did the latest service to my master.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: ANTONY
line: This was the noblest Roman of them all:

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: ANTONY
line: All the conspirators save only he

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: ANTONY
line: Did that they did in envy of great Caesar;

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: ANTONY
line: He only, in a general honest thought

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: ANTONY
line: And common good to all, made one of them.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: ANTONY
line: His life was gentle, and the elements

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: ANTONY
line: So mix'd in him that Nature might stand up

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: ANTONY
line: And say to all the world 'This was a man!'

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: According to his virtue let us use him,

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: With all respect and rites of burial.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: Within my tent his bones to-night shall lie,

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: Most like a soldier, order'd honourably.

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: So call the field to rest; and let's away,

scene: SCENE V.  Another part of the field.
speaker: OCTAVIUS
line: To part the glories of this happy day.
